revisionDesc.change: Vote - AcceptText - Fine. Before finalising, please add the name of contributor at the end of the commentary (and proofread).
Vote - AcceptText - This commentary is more appropriate than regularizing the text, I feel.

The ll. 3â€“4 imply that the writer copied the information from a register (or from the original receipt), and he may have simply misread the original Î´(Î¹Î¬) as (á½‘Ï€Î­Ï), as both might look similar when fluently/rashly/carelessly written.

item.p: In l. 1, (á½‘Ï€Î­Ï) is to be read as Î´Î¹Î¬. While the writer clearly wrote (á½‘Ï€Î­Ï) on the papyrus, it cannot be doubted that the document requires Î´Î¹Î¬ at that position. It introduces the name of the actual payer of the amount due from the onoma (i.e., the fiscal account) of Apollos, son of Dioskoros; see P.Lond. 5.1665.1, SB 20.15013.1 and 4, SB 20.15015.6, SB 24.15975.1, and SB 26.16523.1. The text later (ll. 3â€“4) implies that the writer copied the information from a register (or from the original receipt), and he may have simply misread the original Î´(Î¹Î¬) as (á½‘Ï€Î­Ï), as both might look similar when written by a swift hand. [M. Stern]
